New Library
Progress is finally coming. An authoritative source
told the News-Letter some weeks ago that a new library
has been needed for fifteen years. Plans announced today,
when developed, will satisfy the need.
But undergraduates will question whether the site
of the new building will destroy Homewood's beauty. We
hope assurances to the contrary will prove correct.

Hullabalooing Clan, Agape With Woe-II
A few years ago a top-ranking University administrator remarked: "When there is a conflict of interests,
someone always gets it in the neck." The undergraduates
have had a sore neck for too long.
Since 1955-6, tuition has increased once already and
will repeat its raise of $200 next year. We have a right
to expect something more than we are now getting for our
dollars, and we are getting less than one would expect in
a curriculum of "one of the nation's leading private universities."
Courses are lacking in Russian, Chinese and other
important languages presently essential in today's world
studies in developing cultural and political areas, American literature and drama and music also are wanting. The
Art and Social Relations departments are embryonic, at
best, and even they are for graduate students primarily.
Is it that there is no felt need for such studies; that
there are no qualified professors here or able to be hired
to teach because of tight budgeting; that the qualified
teachers here are too busy with research, or that the present curriculum is deemed satisfactory? It may justifiably
be argued that a lack of money and physicial facilities
impede widening the curriculum, but no other excuse is
acceptable.
Our pain is increased by the closure of desirable
McCoy courses to undergraduates, on the weak grounds
that they are set up for adult education only. Is this to
presume undergraduates are less capable than adult students, or that the reverse is true? Moreover, McCoy students generally pay less per credit per course than we do.

What should be done when a

local scene? There are those who
urge an all-out program of the

the community." But there are
others who remain skeptical of
the wisdom of the "aggressive"
public approach in dealing with
the professional hatemonger, no
matter how useful that method
may be in other situations.
The rabble-rouser is altogether
dependent upon hate-mongering;
for public attention and support. It is his whole stock-intrade. Publicity is not merely
incense in his nostrils—it is his
very life-blood. Certain vermin
thrive in darkness: here is a
species that spawns and flourishes only in the spotlight. If
we are interested in an effective
antidote for rabble-rousers, some
other technique seems to be indicated than feeding them large
doses of the food that makes
them great.
Silent treatment is the best
treatment—backed by a manysided, long-range program, not
against the lone demagogue, but
against the basic evil of race
hate. But the silent treatment
requires self-restraint. Agencies
that practice the method keep

themselves informed of the
activities of anti-Semites and
circulate the information to
journalists, radio commentators,
and others who mold opinion.

And to circulate the truth about

channels requires far more work
and planning than proclaiming

The silent treatment also has
the task of explaining to people
why legislation prohibiting the
incitement of racial and religious
hatred does not exist and would
not be effective. American trapublic opinion does not seem
receptive to further limitations
on freedom of speech. Newspapers are especially quick to
express displeasure at the suggestion that new curbs be placed

prevent talk.

practiced. Those who have employed the silent therapy have
helped to keep rabble-rousing in

lunatic-fringe activity. The antidote for rabble-rousing is much
the same as for all racial and

fight the rabble-rousers is by
fostering attitudes that reject

New Library
Progress is finally coming. An authoritative source
told the News-Letter some weeks ago that a new library
has been needed for fifteen years. Plans announced today,
when developed, will satisfy the need.
But undergraduates will question whether the site
of the new building will destroy Homewood's beauty. We
hope assurances to the contrary will prove correct.

Hullabalooing Clan, Agape With Woe-II
A few years ago a top-ranking University administrator remarked: "When there is a conflict of interests,
someone always gets it in the neck." The undergraduates
have had a sore neck for too long.
Since 1955-6, tuition has increased once already and
will repeat its raise of $200 next year. We have a right
to expect something more than we are now getting for our
dollars, and we are getting less than one would expect in
a curriculum of "one of the nation's leading private universities."
Courses are lacking in Russian, Chinese and other
important languages presently essential in today's world
studies in developing cultural and political areas, American literature and drama and music also are wanting. The
Art and Social Relations departments are embryonic, at
best, and even they are for graduate students primarily.
Is it that there is no felt need for such studies; that
there are no qualified professors here or able to be hired
to teach because of tight budgeting; that the qualified
teachers here are too busy with research, or that the present curriculum is deemed satisfactory? It may justifiably
be argued that a lack of money and physicial facilities
impede widening the curriculum, but no other excuse is
acceptable.
Our pain is increased by the closure of desirable
McCoy courses to undergraduates, on the weak grounds
that they are set up for adult education only. Is this to
presume undergraduates are less capable than adult students, or that the reverse is true? Moreover, McCoy students generally pay less per credit per course than we do.
We note too that the faculty is definitely shirking its
duty to teach when it (1) instructs usually for no more than
a general norm of four hours a week and (2) does not
offer some of its best and most interesting and
valuable courses every year, but, rather, condescends to
give them every other year.
Moreover, the advising system, depending as it does in
great part on the student for his initiative and ability to
make it function, nevertheless involves definite faculty
responsibility—the responsibility to at least be in one's
offices on the two days a year when undergraduates are
required by the Registrar's office to see their advisors
without receiving what, in many other cases, is curt rebuke
or token acknowledgement of troubles.
Perhaps the seventeen who failed out this term would
have not done so if they had been treated with more
faculty time and consideration. Wasted brainpower—
a fault of the student only? He must bear a great burden
of the blame, but certainly not all.
And in this line we cannot help note that some of
the greatest research professors here are also great teachers—respected by their students for stimulating courses
and a sensible open-door policy toward undergraduates
who have academic problems to solve or have scholastic
interests in which they seek the encouragement which
the faculty alone can provide. No doubt the professors
must have time and freedom to do research, for their
ability to teach depends, partly on their ability to learn
new things for themselves and others. But no doubt too
that their teaching ability depends also on communicating
with undergraduates—even if only within the most settled
office hours.
Another example of the guillotining of undergraduates
is the stringent reading period and exam week schedule
which, for all intents, is designed not to disturb the begining and end of the academic year, but which, in weaving
its effects, insidiously achieves the unnecessary harrowing
of crammed undergraduate minds.
And we must note that while a new library has been
needed for fifteen years, a presidential home was built on
campus before the plans for the new library were even
announced. But we must also modify our apparent dismay
because, to the man who initiated the library plans, there
must be a proper reward, and we welcome Milton Eisenhower to residential Homewood, hoping his doors will
remain open to undergraduates.

urge an all-out program of the

others who remain skeptical of
the wisdom of the "aggressive"
public approach in dealing with
the professional hatemonger, no
matter how useful that method
may be in other situations.
The rabble-rouser is altogether
dependent upon hate-mongering;
for public attention and support. It is his whole stock-intrade. Publicity is not merely
incense in his nostrils—it is his
very life-blood. Certain vermin
thrive in darkness: here is a
species that spawns and flourishes only in the spotlight. If
we are interested in an effective
antidote for rabble-rousers, some
other technique seems to be indicated than feeding them large
doses of the food that makes
them great.
Silent treatment is the best
treatment—backed by a manysided, long-range program, not
against the lone demagogue, but
against the basic evil of race
hate. But the silent treatment
requires self-restraint. Agencies
that practice the method keep

activities of anti-Semites and

journalists, radio commentators,
